verb.description: Grant to (someone) the use of (something) on the understanding that it shall be returned.
examples: Stewart asked me to lend him my car
the pictures were lent to each museum in turn
synonyms: let someone have the use of

verb.description: Contribute or add (something, especially a quality) to.
examples: the smile lent his face a boyish charm
John stiffly lent himself to her enthusiastic embraces

phrases: the Samaritans lend their ears to those in crisis
Let her know that you don't necessarily expect her to fix everything for you - you just want her to lend an ear.
Whenever I needed to talk about Aaron, which I admit was often, he always lent an ear.
He wanted to lend an ear but this wasn't part of the bargain.
But for some semblance of camaraderie, lend an ear to their tales of woe.
origin: Old English lǣnan, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch lenen, also to loan. The addition of the final -d in late Middle English was due to association with verbs such as bend and send.
